row.entry: Summary note

These provisions permit a plaintiff to obtain judgment where a defendant has failed to file or verify a defence and where a defence has been struck out. They govern the application procedure and the available forms of judgment.

These provisions specify the permissible forms of default judgment, and the required supporting affidavit evidence, for various specified claims, including claims for possession of land, detention of goods, the recovery of debts, liquidated and unliquidated claims, mixed claims and claims for costs alone.
Application

This Part applies to all courts in UCPR Sch 1 except r 16.4 which does not apply to the Local Court, Small Claims Division and civil proceedings in the Industrial Court or the Industrial Relations Commission: see r 1.5 and Sch 1.
Historical Note
The Part substantially repeats the former SCR Part 17, DCR Part 13 and LCR Part 11. It includes, within the concept of default, the position where a defence has been struck out.
Quick index
Affidavit in support ‥ [16.6.20]

Default judgment on claim for detention of goods, affidavit to support ‥ [r 16.5(2)]
Default judgment on claim for possession of land ‥ [r 16.4]
Default judgment on claim for possession of land, affidavit to support claim for possession ‥ [r 16.4(3)]
Default judgment on claim for unliquidated damages ‥ [r 16.7]
Default judgment on claim for unliquidated damages , affidavit in support ‥ [r 16.7(2)]
Default judgment on debt or liquidated claim ‥ [r 16.6]
Default judgment on debt or liquidated claim, affidavit to support judgment ‥ [r 16.6(2)]
Default judgment on mixed claims ‥ [r 16.8]
Definition of “in default” ‥ [r 16.2]
Description of land ‥ [16.4.5]
Evidence of service of statement of claim ‥ [16.3.7]
Failure to file or verify a defence ‥ [16.2.5]
Form of application for default judgment ‥ [16.3.5]
Judgment for costs alone after other claims satisfied ‥ [r 16.9]
Judgment not limited by plaintiff’s claims for relief ‥ [r 16.10]
Liquidated claim ‥ [16.6.15]

Notice to occupiers and tenants ‥ [16.4.10]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 16.1] r 16.1 Application of Part (cf SCR Part 17, rule 1; DCR Part 13, rule 1; LCR Part 11, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Application of Part (cf SCR Part 17, rule 1; DCR Part 13, rule 1; LCR Part 11, rule 1)

p.text: This Part applies to proceedings commenced by statement of claim.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 16.2] r 16.2 Definition of ″in default″ (cf SCR Part 17, rule 2; DCR Part 13, rule 1; LCR Part 11, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Definition of "in default" (cf SCR Part 17, rule 2; DCR Part 13, rule 1; LCR Part 11, rule 1)

p.text: A defendant is in default for the purposes of this Part:
if the defendant fails to file a defence within the time limited by rule 14.3(1) or within such further time as the court allows, or
if the defendant fails to file any affidavit verifying his or her defence in accordance with any requirement of these rules, or
if, the defendant having duly filed a defence, the court orders the defence to be struck out.
Despite subrule (1), a defendant is not in default if the defendant:
has made a payment towards a liquidated claim under rule 6.17 , or
has filed an acknowledgment of claim under rule 20.34 , or
has filed a defence after the time limited by these rules or allowed by the court, but before a default judgment is given against the defendant.
[subr (2) am Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 6 July 2007]

level.toc-caption: [16.2.5] Failure to file or verify a defence

p.text: Legislation cited in [16.2.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 14.23(2), r 14.28, rr 22.5(1)(b), 23.9(1)(b).

heading.title: Failure to file or verify a defence

p.text: The rule expressly applies in three situations: (i) where a defendant has failed to file a defence in accordance with r 14.3(1); (ii) where a defendant has failed to verify a defence in accordance with r 14.23(2) ; and (iii) where a defence has been struck out (eg, under r 14.28 because it discloses no reasonable defence). The rule does not directly apply to a failure to comply with other rules or with a failure to comply with directions. But the court has a general power to sanction non-compliance with orders and directions, including a power to strike out a defence and enter judgment: see s 61(3) of the CPA. And many provisions of the rules contain additional specific powers to sanction non-compliance: eg, rr 22.5(1)(b) , 23.9(1)(b) . If a defendant fails to comply with a specific direction for the filing of a defence, particularly where the defendant has appeared at, and taken part in, directions hearings in the proceedings, a further application for directions should be made, and that application may include an application for judgment: Altarama Ltd v Forsyth [1981] 1 NSWLR 188 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 16.3] r 16.3 Procedure where defendant in default (cf SCR Part 17, rule 3; DCR Part 13, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Procedure where defendant in default (cf SCR Part 17, rule 3; DCR Part 13, rule 1)

p.text: If a defendant is in default, the plaintiff:
may apply for judgment to be given under this Part, according to the nature of his or her claim for relief, given the defendant in default, and
may carry on the proceedings against any other party to the proceedings.
[subr (1) am Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 6 July 2007]
Unless the court otherwise orders, an application under this rule:
may be dealt with in the absence of the parties, and
need not be served on the defendant.
[subr (1A) insrt Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[29], effective 15 August 2005]
Unless the court orders otherwise, an application for judgment to be given under this Part must be accompanied by:
an affidavit of service of the statement of claim (the affidavit of service), and
an affidavit in support of the application (the affidavit in support).
[subr (2) am Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 6 July 2007]
An affidavit of service is unnecessary in relation to a statement of claim whose service has been effected by the Local Court under rule 10.1(2) .
[subr (3) am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[1], effective 6 July 2009]
Unless the court orders otherwise, an affidavit in support is valid for the purposes of an application only if it has been sworn within 14 days before the date on which the application is filed.

level.toc-caption: [16.3.5] Form of application for default judgment

heading.title: Form of application for default judgment

p.text: An application for default judgment should be made by Notice of Motion — even though the rules do not explicitly so require — conditionally seek dispensation with any requirement for service of the application and seek judgment to be given in the absence of the parties. The approved forms for the relevant Notices of Motion are:
Default judgment on claim for possession of land.
Default judgment for detention of goods.
Default judgment for liquidated claim.
Default judgment for unliquidated damages.

level.toc-caption: [16.3.7] Evidence of service of statement of claim

heading.title: Evidence of service of statement of claim

p.text: The applicant for default judgment must provide clear evidence of service of the statement of claim. Irrespective of whether or not service has been effected by post, or personally, there must be reliable evidence of the despatch or delivery and the contents of the relevant documents. If service by post is relied on, the evidence should detail the addressee, the actual documents despatched and the circumstances of the posting. Imprecise statements that an envelope “was posted” (or delivered) risk being rejected as insufficient evidence of service: Northumbrian Ice Cream Co Ltd v Breakaway Vending Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 1216; BC200609566 at [12] (evidence required of (i) address (ii) correct postage (iii) the actual documents posted, and (iv) actual posting); compare Renegade Rigging Pty Ltd v Hanlon Nominees Pty Ltd [2010] VSC 385; BC201006283 at [24] (evidence of usual “posting” procedures and compliance with them).

level.toc-caption: [16.3.10] Notice of intention to make application for default judgment

p.text: Legislation cited in [16.3.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 36.15 and 36.16.

heading.title: Notice of intention to make application for default judgment

p.text: A plaintiff who applies for default judgment under this Part is not explicitly required to give the defaulting defendant notice (other than that contained in the Statement of Claim itself) of the intended application for judgment: Micallef v ICI Australia Operations Pty Ltd [2001] NSWCA 274; BC200104963 at [89] citing Witten v Lombard Australia Ltd [1968] 2 NSWR 529; (1968) 88 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 405 at 410 (cases rejecting the requirement for prior notice of an intention to apply for dismissal for want of prosecution).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 16.4] r 16.4 Default judgment on claim for possession of land (cf SCR Part 17, rule 7)

leg:heading.title: Default judgment on claim for possession of land (cf SCR Part 17, rule 7)

p.text: Subject to rule 36.8 , if the plaintiff’s claim against a defendant in default is for possession of land only, judgment may be given for the plaintiff for possession of land, as against the defendant, and for costs.
[subr (1) am Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 6 July 2007]
If, before judgment is given, any person files notice of motion for the person’s addition as a defendant, judgment may not be given under this rule until the motion is disposed of.
[subr (2) am Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 6 July 2007]
The relevant affidavit in support:
must identify any persons (other than parties to the proceedings) who were in occupation of the whole or any part of the land:
as at the time the originating process was filed, or
if the claim for possession arises from an amendment to the originating process, as at the time the amendment was made,

and, if any such person was in occupation of the land pursuant to a right of occupation under a residential tenancy agreement within the meaning of the Residential Tenancies Act 2010, must contain a statement to that effect, and
in relation to each such person:
must state that the person’s occupation of the land is not to be disturbed, or
must state that the person is no longer in occupation of any part of the land, or
must state that the person has been served with a notice pursuant to rule 6.8 and that the time allowed for the person to apply to the court to be joined as a defendant has now passed,
as the case requires, and

if the claim for possession of the land arises from a default in the payment of money, must give particulars of the default (including any payments made to date to reduce the amount owing and the current amount owing taking into account any such payments), and

must state the source of the deponent’s knowledge of the matters stated in the affidavit concerning the occupation of the land and any default in the payment of money referred to in paragraph (c), and
must state whether costs are claimed and, if so, how much is claimed for costs, indicating:
how much is claimed on account of professional costs (not exceeding the amount fixed by the regulations made for the purposes of section 329 of the Legal Profession Act 2004), and
how much is claimed on account of filing fees, and
how much is claimed on account of the costs of serving the originating process, and
must state when and how the originating process was served on the defendant.

[subr (3) am Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[16]–[17], effective 8 December 2006; Act 27 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 2.58, effective 4 July 2007; Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[9], [10], effective 7 December 2007 ; Amendment 29 of 2009 Sch 1[10], effective 8 October 2009; Amendment 44 of 2011 Sch 1[1], effective 15 April 2011 ; Amendment 47 of 2011 Sch 1[1], effective 9 September 2011]

A reference in this rule to a residential tenancy agreement within the meaning of the Residential Tenancies Act 2010 is taken to include a reference to a residential tenancy agreement within the meaning of the Residential Tenancies Act 1987 as in force before its repeal.
[subr (4) insrt Amendment 44 of 2011 Sch 1[2], effective 15 April 2011]
The approved form is Form 36 : Notice of motion — default judgment on claim for possession of land.
Legislation cited in [16.4.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 4.7A.
Any originating process planning possession of land, and any judgement or order for possession, must include a description of the proper title of the land: see UCPR r 4.7A .
Legislation cited in [16.4.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 16.4(3)(a), r 36.8, r 6.8(1), r 6.8(2).

Any person occupying the land must be given notice of the proceedings and informed either that they can apply to be joined in the proceedings, or that their continuing occupation will not be disturbed: see UCPR r 6.8(1) . The notice may be served either personally on the occupier or by leaving a notice, addressed to the occupier, on the land: see UCPR r 6.8(2) . If a person is in occupation pursuant to a residential tenancy agreement, the affidavit required by UCPR r 36.8 to support an application for default judgment must disclose that tenancy: see r 16.4(3)(a) and Form 36.

level.toc-caption: [16.4.15] Sheriff required to give notice before enforcement

heading.title: Sheriff required to give notice before enforcement

p.text: The sheriff must give any occupier of land not less than 30 days notice to vacate before acting to enforce any writ for possession or levy of property: Sheriff Act 2005 s 7A. If a residential tenancy is terminated, as a consequence of a mortgagee becoming entitled to exclusive possession of the property, the residential tenant is entitled to withhold (or recover) any rent that would otherwise apply during the 30 day notice period: Residential Tenancies Act 2010 s 122.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 16.5] r 16.5 Default judgment on claim for detention of goods (cf SCR Part 17, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Default judgment on claim for detention of goods (cf SCR Part 17, rule 6)

p.text: If the plaintiff’s claim against a defendant in default relates to the detention of goods only, judgment may be given for the plaintiff against the defendant, in accordance with the plaintiff’s claim:
for delivery of the goods to the plaintiff and for costs, or
for payment to the plaintiff of the value of the goods (as assessed by or in accordance with the directions of the court) and for costs,
at the plaintiff’s option.
See Part 30 for provisions as to assessment of value of goods.
[subr (1) am Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 6 July 2007]
The relevant affidavit in support:
must state which goods have, and which have not, been delivered to the plaintiff since the time the originating process was filed, and

must give particulars of any payments that the defendant has made to the plaintiff in respect of the goods or state that no such payments have been made, as the case may be, since the time the originating process was filed, and
must state the source of the deponent’s knowledge of the matters stated in the affidavit concerning the delivery or non-delivery of the goods, and
must state whether costs are claimed and, if so, how much is claimed for costs, indicating:
how much is claimed on account of professional costs (not exceeding the amount fixed by the regulations made for the purposes of section 329 of the Legal Profession Act 2004), and
how much is claimed on account of filing fees, and
how much is claimed on account of the costs of serving the originating process, and
must state when and how the originating process was served on the defendant,

[subr (2) am Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[16]–[17], effective 8 December 2006; Act 27 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 2.58, effective 4 July 2007; am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[11], [12], effective 7 December 2007]
The approved form is Form 37 : Notice of Motion — Default Judgment for Detention of Goods.

If the plaintiff’s claim is to recover the actual goods detained, the court may order the defendant to return the goods without giving the defendant the option of retaining them and paying their value: Hymas v Ogden [1905] 1 KB 246 . If the plaintiff’s claim is only to recover the value of the goods and damages for their detention, or if it is not practicable to recover the specific goods, then damages are assessed in the same way as any other unliquidated damages. The value of the goods and the damages for detention up to that date must be assessed separately: General and Finance Facilities Ltd v Cooks Cars (Romford) Ltd [1963] 2 All ER 314; [1963] 1 WLR 644 . The value of the goods is determined at the date of the judgment or verdict: Rosenthal v Alderton & Sons Ltd [1946] 1 KB 374; [1946] 1 All ER 583 ; and see A I Ogus, Ogus on Damages, LexisNexis Butterworths, 1973.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 16.6] r 16.6 Default judgment on debt or liquidated claim (cf SCR Part 17, rule 4; DCR Part 13, rule 1; LCR Part 11, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Default judgment on debt or liquidated claim (cf SCR Part 17, rule 4; DCR Part 13, rule 1; LCR Part 11, rule 1)

p.text: If the plaintiff’s claim against a defendant in default is for a debt or liquidated claim or for a claim for unliquidated damages of the kind referred to in rule 14.13(2), judgment may be given for the plaintiff against the defendant for:
a sum not exceeding the sum claimed, and
interest up to judgment, and
costs.
[subr (1) am Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 6 July 2007]
The relevant affidavit in support:
must state the amount due to the plaintiff, in respect of the cause of action for which the proceedings were commenced, as at the time the originating process was filed, and
must give particulars of any reduction of that amount, and costs, as a consequence of any payments made, or credits accrued, since the time the originating process was filed, and
must state the source of the deponent’s knowledge of the matters stated in the affidavit concerning the debt or debts, and
must state the amount claimed by way of interest, and
must state whether costs are claimed and, if so, how much is claimed for costs, indicating:
how much is claimed on account of professional costs (not exceeding the amount fixed by the regulations made for the purposes of section 329 of the Legal Profession Act 2004), and
how much is claimed on account of filing fees, and
how much is claimed on account of the costs of serving the originating process, and
must state when and how the originating process was served on the defendant.

[subr (2) am Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[16]–[17], effective 8 December 2006; Act 27 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 2.58, effective 4 July 2007; am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[13], [14], effective 7 December 2007]
The approved form is Form 38 : Notice of Motion — Default Judgment for Liquidated Claim.
Legislation cited in [16.6.7] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 14.13(2), r 16.6.

The philosophy underlying UCPR r 16.6 is the absence of a timely defence should ordinarily be taken as an admission of the pleaded allegations set out in the statement of claim: Wily v King [2010] NSWSC 352; BC201002510 at [16] per Barrett J. But that ordinary position is subject to the court’s overriding discretion, and its obligation to be satisfied that the entry of judgment is appropriate: Wily v King, above at [17] per Barrett J citing Charles v Shepherd [1892] 2 QB 622 at 624 Lord Esher MR.

The rule does not apply to proceedings other than those for a debt or liquidated demand (or a limited category of claims involving damages to motor vehicles — see UCPR r 14.13(2) . It does not apply to proceedings commenced under other provisions of the rules: Wily v King, above at [27]–[31]per Barrett J (proceedings under the Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules).
Legislation cited in [16.6.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 100.

A claim for interest, including a claim for statutory interest of the kinds specified in the Dictionary definition of “interest up to judgment”, is a claim for a liquidated demand for the purpose of the UCPR. This includes a claim for interest under CPA s 100 . The rule specifically authorises default judgment to be given in an amount that includes an amount for interest up to the date of the judgment. The effect of the definition of “interest up to judgment” is to distinguish, at least in relation to the statutory interest powers referred to in the definition, the decision in Dalgety Futures Pty Ltd v Poretsky [1980] 2 NSWLR 646 (interest claim involving the exercise of a statutory discretion and was not a claim for a liquidated demand under the general law).
Legislation cited in [16.6.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 6.3.
The concept of a “liquidated claim” is considered in detail, and various examples of matters that have been held to fall within the expression are given, in the annotations to UCPR r 6.3 .

A liquidator’s cause of action under s 588M of the Corporations Act (to recover money “as a debt due to the company” is not a “for a debt or liquidated claim”, cannot properly be commenced by a statement of liquidated claim and is not amenable to default judgment: Wily v King [2010] NSWSC 352; BC201002510 at [21] per Barrett J.

Even if the description of the amount claimed, and the basis for its quantification, is capable of falling within the description of a “liquidated demand” the pleading itself must sufficiently allege all of the material facts necessary to establish the basis of the claim. For example, a claim to recover the amount of an asserted contractual liability is not sufficiently pleaded as a liquidated claim unless it sets out the asserted fulfilment of all of the conditions precedent to the defendant’s payment obligation. For example a claim to recover a purchase price that is payable for the transfer of assets must assert the transfer: Arnold v Forsythe [2012] NSWCA 18; BC201200771 at [50]–[59].
Legislation cited in [16.6.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 CPA ss 14, 61(3)(c).

It is implicit in UCPR r 16.6 that an application for default judgment will ordinarily be initiated by a plaintiff. A defendant’s default enlivens the permission conferred by UCPR r 16.3 . The exercise of that permission is conditional on a plaintiff providing an affidavit in support. Such an affidavit is necessary, irrespective of CPA ss 14 , 61(3)(c) and UCPR r 12.7(2) , to provide the court with a proper evidentiary basis for quantifying any judgment or order: Gregory’s Transport Pty Ltd v Ray’s Haulage Pty Ltd [2008] NSWCA 333; BC200810813 ; Ion v Danutz [2012] NSWSC 941; BC201206965 . See also [13.1.45] in relation to dealing with applications for summary judgment.

Even if there is a supporting affidavit, its failure to comply with the substantive requirements of UCPR r 16.6(2) may justify setting aside the default judgment. And the non-compliance, because it raises only a question of law, may be relied on in an appeal, even if the point was not taken at first instance: Arnold v Forsythe [2012] NSWCA 18; BC201200771 at [88]. The supporting affidavit will be irregular, for example, if it claims that the source of the knowledge of the debt (see UCPR r 16.6(2)(c) ) is merely general familiarity with the proceedings or responsibility for their conduct: Arnold v Forsythe [2012] NSWCA 18; BC201200771 at [88](iii).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 16.7] r 16.7 Default judgment on claim for unliquidated damages (cf SCR Part 17, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Default judgment on claim for unliquidated damages (cf SCR Part 17, rule 5)

p.text: If the plaintiff’s claim against a defendant in default is for unliquidated damages only, judgment may be given for the plaintiff against the defendant for damages to be assessed and for costs.
See Part 30 for provisions as to assessment of damages.
[subr (1) am Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 6 July 2007]
The relevant affidavit in support:
must state that the matter has not been settled with the defendant, and
must state the source of the deponent’s knowledge of the matters stated in the affidavit concerning the claim, and
must state whether costs are claimed and, if so, how much is claimed for costs, indicating:
how much is claimed on account of professional costs (not exceeding the amount fixed by the regulations made for the purposes of section 329 of the Legal Profession Act 2004), and
how much is claimed on account of filing fees, and
how much is claimed on account of the costs of serving the originating process, and
must state when and how the originating process was served on the defendant.

[subr (2) am Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[16]–[17], effective 8 December 2006; Act 27 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 2.58, effective 4 July 2007; am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[15], [16], effective 7 December 2007]
The approved form is Form 39 : Notice of Motion — Default Judgment for Unliquidated Damages.
Legislation cited in [16.7.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 14.13(2).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 16.8] r 16.8 Default judgment on mixed claims (cf SCR Part 17, rule 8)

leg:heading.title: Default judgment on mixed claims (cf SCR Part 17, rule 8)

p.text: If the plaintiff’s claim against a defendant in default includes any 2 or more of the claims referred to in this Part, and no other claim, judgment may be given for the plaintiff against the defendant on any of those claims as if it were the plaintiff’s only claim for relief against that defendant.
[subr (2) am Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 6 July 2007]
In the case of two or more such claims, the relevant affidavit in support must comply with the requirements of this Part in relation to each of those claims.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 16.9] r 16.9 Judgment for costs alone after other claims satisfied (cf SCR Part 17, rule 10(1); DCR Part 31, rule 13; LCR Part 26, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Judgment for costs alone after other claims satisfied (cf SCR Part 17, rule 10(1); DCR Part 31, rule 13; LCR Part 26, rule 4)

p.text: If a plaintiff is entitled to have judgment entered under this Part against a defendant in default for any relief and for costs, but it appears by affidavit that, by reason of the defendant having satisfied the plaintiff’s claims, it is unnecessary for the plaintiff to continue the proceedings against the defendant, judgment for the plaintiff may be given under this Part against that defendant for costs alone.
[subr (1) am Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 6 July 2007]
Whatever the plaintiff’s claims for relief against a defendant in default, if:
the defendant satisfies the plaintiff’s claims or complies with the plaintiff’s demands, or
it otherwise becomes unnecessary for the plaintiff to continue the proceedings against the defendant,
the court may, on application by the plaintiff, give judgment against the defendant for costs.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 16.10] r 16.10 Judgment not limited by plaintiff’s claims for relief (cf SCR Part 17, rules 9 and 10(2))

leg:heading.title: Judgment not limited by plaintiff’s claims for relief (cf SCR Part 17, rules 9 and 10(2))

p.text: Whatever the plaintiff’s claims for relief against a defendant in default, the court may, on application by the plaintiff, give such judgment against the defendant as the plaintiff appears to be entitled to on his or her statement of claim.
